title: Integrate with HCM
content:
Note

The SMAX-HCM integration has been deprecated since the 2020.05 release, and may be obsoleted in a future release. Customers can deploy and enable the Design and Deploy (DND) capability to use aggregated offerings instead of this integration (see Create and edit aggregation providers). 

This topic describes two use cases based on an integration between SMAX and OpenText Hybrid Cloud Management (HCM):

  • VM provisioning in HCM via SMAX Service Portal
  • VM provisioning failure handling in SMAX-HCM

It also provides step-by-step guidance for setting up the SMAX-HCM integration to support the use cases.

Use case 1: VM provisioning in HCM via SMAX Service Portal

In this use case, Amy, as one R&D engineer, needs to request one new Linux VM from vCenter for her daily work. Knowing that the SMAX Self-Service Portal is integrated with HCM so that end users may request VMs from the Portal directly and that she has access to a variety of self-service support features such as catalog, knowledge, and subscription management for the applications she uses every day, Amy decides to give it a try.

Step 1: End user accesses self-service portal

Amy logs into the SMAX Self-Service Portal. The landing page is displayed.

Step 2: End user submits VM Request with the help of Virtual Agent

Amy proceeds to get help from the Virtual Agent available in the portal, by specifying vCenter VM instance. The Virtual Agent assists by providing her with a list of VM related requests, and Amy selects Request a new Vcenter Server instance.

Amy reviews the properties of the VM that she is requesting. It's a Ubuntu VM of the medium size, which is what she needs. Amy clicks SUBMIT to submit the request.

Step 3: IT Agent approves VM request

According to the company's IT policy, requests for VMs of a size larger than "Micro" need an IT agent’s approval. Alex, as the agent to monitor the SMAX-HCM integration, notices Amy’s request and approves it after reviewing the VM size.

Step 4: HCM fulfillment tasks run to completion

Knowing that the HCM fulfillment tasks will be auto triggered after his approval, Alex navigates to Task plan in Amy’s request to monitor the progress. After about one minute, all of the three tasks are completed, which means that the HCM VM provisioning has actually started.

Step 5: Agent checks HCM subscription details via SMAX request

Alex wants to check the VM provisioning status at the HCM side. To do this, he navigates to the General tab in Amy’s request, drills down to the Catalog Offering section, and finds the HCM Subscription Link which is returned by HCM.

Alex clicks the link, which brings him to the HCM subscription detail page for the VM instance being provisioned per Amy’s request. It's still in Pending status.

Step 6: Agent gets HCM subscription status via SMAX request

Alex knows SMAX can auto scan the HCM subscription status on an hourly basis; however, HCM VM provisioning normally takes only 10 to 15 minutes. One hour is too long. Ten minutes after the completion of the request tasks, Alex decides to check the subscription status manually. He re-opens Amy’s request, clicks Get HCM Subscription Status from the More > HCM menu.

The request is then refreshed, and automatically moves to the Close phase.

Now, Alex knows that the VM provisioning has succeeded at the HCM side. He navigates to Discussions in the request and finds the success feedback.

Step 7: End users gets success feedback and logs in to VM

Amy logs in to Service Portal and checks her request status. Her request is closed and the "success" feedback is displayed in Interactions area.

She opens the link provided, and then clicks View Linked Service to check the IP address of the new VM provisioned for her. Now, she can log in to the new VM for her daily work.


Use case 2: VM provisioning failure handling in SMAX-HCM

In this use case, we will simulate a VM provisioning failure at the HCM side, and one incident will be created in SMAX and linked to the service request submitted previously by Amy. Amy will be notified of the failure, and the system will switch to the incident process to resolve the issue before provisioning a new VM instance for Amy.

Most of the steps are same as those in user case 1. To simulate a VM provisioning failure, Amy enters an invalid value for Datacenter Name (for example CICDDatacenter or CICD_Datacenter1), and submits the request.

As usual, Alex approves Amy’s request and observes that all of three tasks run to completion in the request. After 10 minutes, he clicks the Get HCM Subscription Status menu item to check the status; however, this time the service request gets stuck in the "Fulfill" phase, which indicates something may be wrong with the VM provisioning.

Alex navigates to Discussions in the request and finds the "failure" feedback.

As it Since the screen indicates that one incident has been created and linked, Alex navigates to Related records and then finds the newly created incident. This incident is used to track the VM provisioning failure until it's resolved.

Alex also checks the HCM subscription URL provided in the feedback. The failure information is displayed.

Amy logs in to SMAX Service Portal to check the request status. The Interactions tab indicates that the VM provisioning failed, and a related incident has been created to track the issue.

Now, Alex needs to work with the support team to figure out the root cause, and then provides a solution to resolve the incident before he can continue to fulfill Amy’s request.

Behind the scenes: setting up the integration

Here is a summary of the steps to configure the SMAX-HCM integration shown above:

SMAX side:

  1.  Set up an On-Premises Bridge agent.
  2. Add an Operations Orchestration (OO) endpoint for invoking OO flows.
  3. Add a REST execution endpoint for invoking OO flows via a REST API.
  4. Create new fields for requests and offerings.
  5. Expose the new fields in request and offering forms.
  6. Configure one catalog offering:
    • User Options
    • Rules
    • Task Plan
    • Default Values
  7. Configure workflow rules for the service request.
  8. Configure a custom action for the service request.
  9. Configure an Incident model.
  10. Configure service portal settings.

HCM side:

  1.  Apply the OO content pack.
  2. Configure flow parameters in the OO Central Server.

SMAX

Step 1: Set up an On-Premises Bridge agent

Before you begin, you may want to read general background details for setting up integrations in On-Premises Bridge Agents and Endpoints.

This document includes further information on setting up the On-Premise Bridge, which is used to enable REST integration communication from SMAX to external systems.

Note:  Be sure to import the SMAX CA certificate and OO CA certificate into the On-Premises Bridge so that OPB can establish a connection to SMAX and OO. For detailed instructions, see How to import certificates into OPB.

Step 2: Add an OO endpoint for invoking OO flows

Once you have an On-Premise Bridge (OPB) endpoint agent available, the next step is to add an End Point that will be used to call our flows in the OO system: 

  1. In the Administration Menu, navigate to Integration Management > ENDPOINTS.
  2. Press the +Add button to create a new Endpoint:
    1. Select Operations Orchestration as the Endpoint type. 
    2. Provide a name or the endpoint (for example: HCM OO Integration) .
    3. Specify the OPB agent that will enable the endpoint.
    4. Click ADD.
  3. Once created, configure the Endpoint:
    1. Enter the OO URL location. For example: https://myoohost.mycompany.net:8444.
    2. Select the credentials that you entered in the OPB to connect to the OO Server.
  4. Click Test connection to make sure the connection is successful.

Step 3: Add a REST execution endpoint for invoking OO flows via REST APIs

In addition, we need to add another endpoint that will be used to call REST APIs into the OO system. This is because workflow rules can only call REST APIs to run OO flows to periodically get the HCM subscription status, which we will introduce in following sections.

Follow the similar steps in

Configure the same URL (for example: https://myhost.mycompany.net:8444) as the URL location, and then select related credentials.

Step 4: Create new fields for requests and offerings

We define a number of new fields for service requests. These fields are used to store OO output values after the Create Subscription Service OO flow triggers the HCM fulfillment process. Refer to the following table and screenshot.

Field Name Purpose
HCMSubscriptionFlowStatus_c Store the return result of OO flow "Subscription Status" in a RESTful call.
HCMSubscriptionId_c Store the HCM request ID generated by OO flow "Create Subscription Service".
HCMSubscriptionLink_c Store the HCM subscription detail URL, and URL type.
HCMSubscriptionStatus_c Store the HCM subscription status.
HCMSubscriptionStatusUUID_c Store the UUID of OO flow "Subscription Status" for a RESTful API to call.
HCMSubscriptionURL_c Store the HCM subscription detail URL text, to convert into an http link.

We also define three fields for offerings. These fields are used to record the HCM offering name, and provide the incident model ID for HCM to create an incident in case the HCM fulfillment fails.

Field Name Purpose
HCMOfferingDisplayName_c Store the HCM offering name. Not needed if the HCM offering is aggregated to Service Management.
IncidentModelId_c Store the incident model ID by which HCM can create an incident if the fulfillment fails.
TenantId_c Store the tenant ID by which HCM can connect to SMAX to create the incident.

Step 5: Expose new fields in request and offering forms

Most of the fields that have been added for service requests are used in the backend; however, the HCMSubscriptionLink_c field should be displayed as a URL in the "withoutResolution" Request form. This way, the IT agent can find the HCM subscription URL in the service request, and then check the subscription details in HCM via this link.

We display the values of the three fields added for offerings in the "Full Offering form" offering form, so that the IT agent can set the exact HCM offering name here. This is a workaround before HCM offerings can be auto aggregated into Service Management. The IT agent also needs to set the Tenant ID and Incident Model ID for HCM to create an incident in SMAX in case the fulfillment fails. We also display the three fields in the "New Offering form" offering form so that you can set the values when creating a new offering.

Step 6: Configure one catalog offering

We need to create one catalog offering in SMAX to represent the one in HCM, because HCM-SMAX catalog aggregation isn't yet implemented. The following table and figure illustrate an example offering named "Request a new Vcenter Server instance". Pay attention to some attribute values.

Attribute Name Value Comment
HCM Offering Display Name VcenterServerOffering Exact HCM offering name for the fulfillment, which is created in HCM
Tenant Id 381155591 Current tenant ID, passed to HCM for calling back the SMAX tenant
Incident Model Id 17093 Passed to HCM for creating an incident when the fulfillment fails
Offering type Service Offering
Service definition HCM Subscription Business service "HCM Subscription" is created to include the offering

User Options

We need to define a number of user options for end user’s input. The following table describes a list of user options, most of which are required by HCM to start the fulfillment. In particular, we define Option Sets to build a JSON body that includes all user option values to call HCM OO flows.

User Option Name Details Comments
Datacenter Name Field Type: String / Field Size: Medium

Required: Yes / Visibility: User

 Mandatory parameter requested by HCM
VM Folder Field Type: String / Field Size: Medium

Required: Yes / Visibility: User

 Mandatory parameter requested by HCM
VM Templates Field Type: String / Field Size: Medium

Required: Yes / Visibility: User

 Mandatory parameter requested by HCM
VM Name Prefix Field Type: String / Field Size: Medium

Required: No / Visibility: User

 Optional paramater
Instance Type Field Type: List / Field Size: Medium

Required: Yes / Visibility: User

List: Instance Type

List Items: Micro/Small/Medium/Large/Custom

 Specify a VM template size: Micro, Small, Medium, Large, or Custom.
Memory Size Field Type: Numeric / Field Size: Medium

Required: No / Visibility: User

 Specify a memory size if Instance Type is Custom.
Number of CPU Cores Field Type: Numeric / Field Size: Medium

Required: No / Visibility: User

 Specify the number of CPU cores if Instance Type is Custom.

Required: No / Visibility: Agent

 Used to build a JSON body that consists of all of the above user option values and is passed to HCM to trigger the fulfillment.

Rules

Offering rules are defined to handle custom "Instance Types" and how "Option Sets" are built in different situations. We define the rules in the "After change" and "Rendering forms" categories.

After change

First, set ‘Memory Size’ and ‘Number of CPU Cores’ as mandatory. We only set the two user options as mandatory when "Instance Type" is set as "Custom". It requires end users to input the value because they are customized.

Second, build "Option Sets" in different situations. Because end users may customize an "Instance Type" and "VM Name Prefix" is optional, there are different situations in which "Option Sets" are built. The following tables describe four situations.

CAUTION: In the following four situations, the "Option Sets" values are dynamic values. Before copying these values to your environment, you must click the fx icon first. Otherwise, an "Invalid input data" will occur.


Situation-1

If the end user customizes "Instance Type" and sets "VM Name Prefix", then Option Sets consists of all of the 7 user option values.

Condition Option Sets
${entity.UserOptions.VMNamePrefix_c != null && entity.UserOptions.InstanceType_c == 'Custom_c'} ${concat(',"actionProperty": [{ "name": "OPTION_SETS", "values": [{ "value": [{ "displayName": "Deployment Configurations", "options": [{ "displayName": "vCenter Server Configurations", "property": [{ "displayName": "Datacenter Name", "values": [{ "value": "', entity.UserOptions.DatacenterName_c, '" }]},{"displayName":"VM Folder","values":[{"value":"', entity.UserOptions.VMFolder_c,'"}]},{ "displayName": "TemplateName", "values": [{ "value": "', entity.UserOptions.VMTemplates_c, '" }]},{ "displayName": "VM Name Prefix", "values": [{ "value": "', entity.UserOptions.VMNamePrefix_c, '" }]}] }] }] }] }, { "name": "OPTION_SETS", "values": [{ "value": [{ "displayName": "Instance Type", "options": [{"displayName": "', substitute(entity.UserOptions.InstanceType_c, '_c', ''), '","property": [{"displayName": "Memory Size","values": [{"value": "', substitute(entity.UserOptions.MemorySize_c, '.0', ''), '"}]},{"displayName": "Number of CPU Cores","values": [{"value": "', substitute(entity.UserOptions.NumberOfCPUCores_c, '.0', ''), '"}]}]}]}]}]}]')}

For each situation above, the JSON body built in Option Sets aligns with the action properties interface that's defined in HCM. You can refer to the HCM documentation for the interface details:    /itom/Cloud_Service_Automation:4.92/APIs/Subscritption_API#ActionProperties

Rendering forms

We define some rules to hide "Memory Size" and "Number of CPU Cores" if the end user doesn't customize "Instance Type". We also hide "Option Sets", which is transparent to end users.

Task Plan

In Offering, we define tasks in the "Approve" and "Fulfill" phases for service requests, to trigger the fulfillment from SMAX to HCM via OO flows.

Approve phase

SMAX service requests for VM fulfillment need request approval by default. In the following example task definitions, we define that an approval is required for requests for VMs of an "Instance Type" that's bigger than "Micro".

Fulfill phase

In this phase, we define different tasks for different purposes.

Task Name Purpose
HCM fulfillment To invoke OO flow ‘Create Subscription Service’ to trigger HCM fulfillment
Get Subscription URL To invoke OO flow ‘Subscription Status’ to get HCM subscription URL
Convert Subscription URL To convert the HCM subscription URL from text to an http link

Default Values

For this offering, we define default values for some important fields as well as user options. Following screenshot is the example, pay attention to ‘service’ field, we create one new actual service ‘vCenter Computer Service’ for demo purpose. Note: Make sure to check ‘Skip end user acceptance’ checkbox, so that the service request can skip ‘Accept’ phase after HCM fulfillment succeeds.

Step 7: Configure workflow rules for service request

In Step 6, we define the task to trigger HCM fulfillment and get subscription URL, but we don’t keep the task waiting for the fulfillment completes as the task will time out. Instead, we define workflow rules to get subscription status periodically (one hour currently) after the fulfillment starts. We also define custom actions to enable IT agents to manually get subscription status, see Step 8.

If the subscription status is SUCCESS, SMAX will auto close service request, and notify the end user, provide him/her with HCM subscription URL for VM info.

If the subscription status is FAILURE, SMAX will notify the end user too, in addition, an incident is auto created and linked with the service request for issue tracking.

We illustrate 5 rules in ‘Request - Service’ workflow in the following.
CAUTION: In the following example rules, some field values are dynamic values. Before copying these values to your environment, you must click the fx icon first. Otherwise, an "Invalid input data" will occur.

Rule-1

‘Per schedule’ rule to set ‘CustomActionName’ and ‘CustomActionCount’ per hour.

Step 8: Configure custom action for service request

In step 7, we define workflow rules to periodically get HCM subscription status. However, per hour is a bit too long. To save the time, we also define custom action in ‘Request’, so that IT agent may manually press this item to get the status. Typically, HCM VM fulfillment will complete in 10 to 15 minutes, then the agent may check the status to get the update.

Following is the example for custom action ‘GetHCMSubscriptionStatus’.

Note:

a)     Make sure to check ‘Enable workflow’ checkbox.

b)     Action group ‘HCM’ is defined in left panel (via ‘Action groups’ button)

This custom action will then trigger the rules defined in Step 7 to get HCM subscription status.

Step 9: Configure Incident Model

In order for HCM to easily create incident in Service Management, we define one incident model for HCM. Remember incident model ID and we pass it (17093 in our demo) to OO flow ‘Subscription Status’ in step 6 and 7.

We also set default values for some fields in the model, i.e., Service is set as ‘vCenter Computer Service’, which is the actual service we defined before.

Step 10: Configure service portal settings

In order for user options to be visible to end users, we need to set ‘Use the custom request form’ as ‘Custom request form – customizable’ in service portal feature settings.

HCM

Step 1: Apply OO content pack

HCM suite has embedded OO and most of content packs deployed already, what we need is to deploy content pack OO Service Management Content, which you may download from OO Marketplace.

Step 2: Configure flows in the OO Central server

System Accounts

As the next step, we need to configure system accounts to enable OO to access HCM and Service Management. The mandatory system accounts are listed in the following table.

Parameter Comments
HCM Credentials Allow OO to access HCM with the role of admin
HCM Consumer Credentials Allow OO to access HCM with the role of consumer
IDM Credential Allow OO to access IDM in the container
SMAX Credentials Allow OO to access SMAX

The following figure shows an example for all of the credentials listed above.

System Properties

As the next step, we need to configure system properties for OO to access HCM and SMAX URLs properly.

Parameter Comments
consumerportalUrl Allow OO to access consumer portal, i.e.,  https://myconsumerportalhost.mycompany.net:8089/
csaUrl Allow OO to access CSA, i.e., https://mycsahost.mycompany.net:8444/
